nodes.bodyText: Why does webContentsDebuggingEnabled get special treatment? Can this constructor just be public CapConfig(Context context)?
yeah, context is enough to get the debuggable value like this (context.getApplicationInfo().flags & ApplicationInfo.FLAG_DEBUGGABLE) != 0;

Should all this be happening in the constructor? Maybe we can take this opportunity to practice some separation of concerns. The iOS side now has a few different classes that separate "loading from a JSON file" and "containing the configuration".

Thanks for the feedback. I have removed the public constructor for CapConfig and replaced it with a method fromFile that can be used to create an instance of CapConfig from the JSON config file.
I moved the JSON file loading to the FileUtils class since it involved reading a file and seemed appropriate there (and its also reused elsewhere in the core).
I think this should follow the getter pattern: getHTML5Mode() or isHTML5Mode()
I think these should follow the setter pattern: setHTML5Mode(), setServerURL(), etc.
They dont need to, but it seems Android does that so I'll copy their style

I don't think we should add these methods here. Is the intended usage this.bridge.config.getPluginString() in the Plugin class? If so, it would be a nicer API if it was just this.config.getString() (or this.pluginConfig.getString()), etc. We could make a PluginConfig class to keep classes smaller and purposeful.

I split the Plugin JSON config into its own class and moved the methods there also. Since the CapConfig and PluginsConfig class used similar JSON parsing methods, I centralized those in a new class called JSONUtils that both Config classes may use.
Use example:
config.getPluginsConfiguration().getString("myplugin","temperature");
Thoughts?
Looking good so far--check out my latest comment: #3778 (comment)
I would phrase this as isMixedContentAllowed(), otherwise the allow verb makes it seem like this method allows mixed content in the config. Same with captureInput() and hideLogs()
Can this be narrowed to only JSON exceptions?
Little nitpick: this method is returning the plugins configuration. getPluginsConfiguration() might be a more suitable name.
This is a breaking change. Can you add back the other implementation that accepts JSON and deprecate it similar to how the other ones are?

After discussing, the breaking change is acceptable since the use case for using this method included Embedded and edge cases. Will document in upgrade guide. Added some javadoc to highlight that an instance of CapConfig is used instead of a JSONObject.
These appear to be unused. (Might have been my fault when main was merged in)
Since this is already a breaking change, we should just remove it. init() is the deprecated way of initializing the Android bridge.
This looks like a setter, should it be setConfig() ?
reader.close() is never called. new code should use try-with-resources: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/tryResourceClose.html

Is this supposed to be Boolean?
Also, if other boolean getters use is, should this as well?
Even though this not the same class, it's referring to the same property, essentially. Should we call it setLogsHidden() to match isLogsHidden()?
Love this class, but should it go in com.getcapacitor.util?

I think we may have misunderstood each other. I was envisioning a reusable PluginConfig class that would correspond to a single plugin's configuration within the Capacitor config file.
Usage would look like this:
config.getPluginConfig(TEST_PLUGIN_NAME).getString("var2")
Would it make sense to return an empty PluginConfig to avoid possible null exceptions?
Thanks
